title: Lewis and Clark
subtitle: Exploring the West (1804-1806)
narrator: William, age 17, member of the Corps of Discovery, 1805

sections.title: Into the Unknown
sections.summary: I'm William, seventeen, and I'm part of the greatest adventure in American history. Meriwether Lewis and William Clark are leading the Corps of Discovery—about 40 men—to explore the Louisiana Purchase and beyond, all the way to the Pacific Ocean. President Jefferson gave Lewis specific orders: map t...

sections.title: Sacagawea's Help
sections.summary: In North Dakota, we met Sacagawea, a Shoshone woman who joined us as interpreter and guide. She's about sixteen and carries her baby son on her back. Her presence signals peaceful intentions to tribes we meet—no war party travels with a woman and baby.

sections.title: Encounters with Native Peoples
sections.summary: The expedition's success depended entirely on Native peoples. We didn't discover anything—Native nations had lived in and traveled through these lands for thousands of years. They shared knowledge that saved our lives.

sections.title: The Rocky Mountains
sections.summary: Nothing prepared us for the Rocky Mountains. Jefferson hoped we'd find an easy passage—maybe a short portage between rivers. Instead, we found a seemingly endless range of rugged peaks.

sections.title: Reaching the Pacific
sections.summary: On November 7, 1805, we finally saw it—the Pacific Ocean. "Ocean in view! O!

sections.title: What We Discovered
sections.summary: The Lewis and Clark Expedition changed America's vision of itself. Before, Americans thought of their nation as confined to lands east of the Mississippi. After, they imagined a nation spanning the continent.

key_facts: I'm William, seventeen, and I'm part of the greatest adventure in American history.
In North Dakota, we met Sacagawea, a Shoshone woman who joined us as interpreter and guide.
The expedition's success depended entirely on Native peoples.
Jefferson hoped we'd find an easy passage—maybe a short portage between rivers.
On November 7, 1805, we finally saw it—the Pacific Ocean.
The Lewis and Clark Expedition changed America's vision of itself.

vocabulary.definition: The 1804-1806 exploration of Louisiana Purchase and beyond, led by Meriwether Lewis and William Clark.
The name of the expedition group led by Lewis and Clark.
Shoshone woman who served as interpreter and guide for the Lewis and Clark expedition.
Co-leader of the western expedition, chosen by President Jefferson.
Co-leader of the western expedition, skilled mapmaker and frontiersman.
The expedition's goal, reached in November 1805 after crossing the continent.
